newsitem.title: USA: Airbus seeks partners for jetliner - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Airbus seeks partners for jetliner - WSJ.

text.p: Airbus Industrie has been talking to aerospace manufacturers in North America and Asia about possible partnerships in its planned A3XX airliner, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.

In an interview, Volker von Tein, Airbus' chief operating officer, told the newspaper an industrial alliance with a U.S. company could be far-reaching and did not exclude a large-scale manufacturing operation.
Von Tien said potential candidates for a manufacturing alliance could include Canada's Bombardier Inc, Northrop Grumman and Lockheed Martin Corp.
A Northrop spokesman said the company had been contacted by Airbus, a European consortium, to sound out the corporation's interest in the A3XX project.

While Northrop is not interested in making structural components for the large airliner, the spokesman said Northrop is considering the possibility of making engine nacelles for the double-decker jet.
He said, however, that contacts so far had been "strictly exploratory."
Von Tein said other possible industrial partners in the program include Italy's Alenia SpA, a unit of state-owned Finmeccanica.
Von Tein said Airbus cannot exclude Chinese and Russian partners in the A3XX project, although Russia is a remote possibility because manufacturers there are financially strapped.
Airbus plans to launch its long-range A3XX seating 555 passengers in three classes or more than 800 in a single-class layout in time for deliveries in 2003.
